Award.AwardTitle: NSF/FDA SIR: Safer (polymeric) batteries in medical devices and evolving regulatory framework

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Batteries play an important role in the overall function, reliability, and safety of many medical devices such as pacemakers, implantable cardioverter defibrillators, glucose monitoring devices, and wheelchairs. The insights gained in this one-year NSF/FDA Scholar-In-Residence fundamental research project will aid and inform the development of protocols that demonstrate safety and feasibility of polymer electrolytes for lithium batteries. Success of this project will help streamline the regulation of solid polymer electrolytes in medical devices as a safer alternative. In addition to the impacts on science, the project will also broadly impact engineering education, training students of different educational levels and from diverse backgrounds. Several initiatives are planned, including specific programs that assist in undergraduate and graduate education, graduate student mentoring, and training of high school students. <br/><br/>The goal of this project is to better understand the electrochemical, transport, and safety properties of water-containing solid polymer electrolytes. A small amount of water acts as a super plasticizer of the polymer matrix and provides an alternative conduction pathway that significantly improves cation transport. Additionally, the inclusion of water is expected to have a significant impact on the safety of the resulting battery device. Specifically, the Investigatorâ€™s propose to study an aqueous solid polymer electrolyte (ASPE) consisting of varying amounts of polyacrylonitrile (PAN), water, and lithium salt as a model system to probe these questions. An investigation of these ASPEs will focus on determining how salt concentration, water concentration, and polymer molecular weight can affect ionic conductivity, cation transport, electrochemical stability, cell safety, and cell performance. Gaining insight into the water-dominant transport mechanism causing the enhanced electrochemical performance of the proposed ASPE systems will greatly benefit the design of the next generation of batteries for medical devices. Full cell devices will undergo safety testing that will help inform an emerging regulatory framework for assessing the safety of polymer electrolytes for use in medical devices.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Batteries play an important role in the overall function, reliability, and safety of many medical devices such as pacemakers, implantable cardioverter defibrillators, and glucose monitoring devices. As batteries continue to grow in use for medical devices, concerns over their safety have influenced research for alternative materials to replace the currently used highly flammable and electrochemically unstable liquid organic electrolytes.

Our investigation of Aqueous Solid Polymer Electrolytes, ASPEs,  focuses on determining how salt, water, and ionic liquid concentration affect ionic conductivity, cation transport, electrochemical stability, cell safety, and cell performance. The insights gained from this work will aid and inform the development of protocols that demonstrate the feasibility of SPEs as a safer alternative for lithium batteries, particularly for medical devices. Success of this project will greatly benefit the design of the next generation of batteries and help streamline the regulation of SPEs for these devices. In addition to the impacts on science, this ongoing collaboration between FDA and UMD benefits the professional development of graduate students conducting research through outside mentoring and the use of governmental facilities and equipment.

In solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) systems involving polymer, water, lithium salt, and ionic liquid, it is not trivial to assess the function of each component, the relationships among them, or their impacts on properties and performance without resource-intensive techniques and simulations. This is especially important in the electrolyte system we are experimenting on, where water and ionic liquid can contribute to both transport and stability properties in contrary manners. Therefore, to fully investigate and develop the electrolyte system, the following objectives are assessed:

  1. Tune transport properties by establishing composition-function relationships between polymer, water, and lithium salt/plasticizers.
  2. Improve stability and performance by determining how composition-function relationships interplay with stability, interphase formation, and battery performance.
  3. Evaluate safety for medical device use and evolve safety standards for SPEs.

Methods

The electrolyte system under investigation marries the enhanced transport properties of water with the enhanced stability of ionic liquids. Various electrochemical techniques ? electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), cyclic voltammetry (CV), galvanostatic cycling, etc. ? are employed to characterize both the inherent properties (ionic conductivity, ESW) and overall performance of the system (transference number, interphase formation and passivation).  Kyle Ludwig, the graduate student supported on this work was just recently granted FDA access. The delay to his access was due to COVID-19 restrictions. Therefore a no cost-extension has been requested.

Outcomes

A moderate research matrix was designed to investigate the impact of each component (polymer, water, lithium salt, ionic liquid)  on transport properties. EIS and DSC are being performed on each of these compositions, as a first pass, to determine the room-temperature ionic conductivity and the overall morphology on the system. In parallel, TGA is used to determine the total water content to facilitate establishing composition-function relationships. Of the several compositions tested thus far, general trends show that increasing salt concentration leads to increased ionic conductivity (8.85 ? 0.24 mS/cm). The DSC thermogram, shown below, demonstrates the lack of melting/crystallization or glass transition in the temperature range of -20 to 100 ?C, which correlates with the ionic conductivity observed. 

However, there is a limitation to the overall salt concentration (~78 wt%) before phase separation occurs and ionic conductivity plumets due to aggregate formation. Additionally, the high salt concentration leads to increased hygroscopic behavior, making it difficult to control the overall water content, which is crucial for not only being able to accurately determine composition-function relationships but for limiting the negative impact on electrochemical stability.

Moving forward, more recent compositions focus on the effects liquid plasticizers on the system, primarily ionic liquids. The ionic liquids provide a marginal sacrifice of ionic conductivity (preliminary compositions displaying ~3 mS/cm) to reduce the overall hygroscopic behavior and allow precise control of total water content. By matching the anion of the ionic liquid with that of the lithium salt (TFSI-), we also hypothesize that the electrochemical stability will not be diminished since TFSI- reduction leads to LiF formation in the SEI and contributes to passivation. We will validate this hypothesis by comparing the ESW and passivating behavior of the two different regimes of electrolyte ? lithium salt-dominated and ionic liquid-dominated ? to determine if stability was improved by reducing the amount of uncontrolled water absorption in the system.
